Question: With the US GDP  we saw that that the data had an upward trend. We took the first difference but were not able to eliminate the trend. Why do you think the data required a second differencing?
Answer: The data had too steep a slope
The data had an exponential component (increasing slope).
The data were spread out over a long period of time.
Correct: The data had an exponential component (increasing slope).

Question: What is the difference between seasonality and cyclicality?
Answer: Seasonality refers to cycles that repeat on an annual basis. Cyclicality refers to cycles that can be longer than a year.
Seasonality refers to data that varies according to 3-month cycles, the same length as seasons of the year.
There is no difference. Seasonality and cyclicality are the same thing.
Correct: Seasonality refers to cycles that repeat on an annual basis. Cyclicality refers to cycles that can be longer than a year.

Question: Both AR and MA models use previous data to predict the next value of our variable. How are they different?
Answer: AR uses lagged values of the error terms and MA uses lagged values of the data itself.
MA uses lagged values of the error terms and AR uses lagged values of the data itself.
Correct: MA uses lagged values of the error terms and AR uses lagged values of the data itself.

Question: An ARIMA(1,2,3) model includes:
Answer: One lagged error term, two lagged data values and is differenced three times.
One lagged data value, two lagged lagged error terms and is differenced three times.
One lagged data value, three lagged lagged error terms and is differenced twice.
Correct: One lagged data value, three lagged lagged error terms and is differenced twice.
